text:
In J.R.R. Tolkien's Lord of the Rings series, the concept of power is a pervasive and multifaceted theme that explores the corrupting influence of dominance, to the complexities of benevolent rule. The struggle for and maintenance of power serve as the central driving forces behind the plot, and shapes the actions of its characters.

The primary example of the allure and danger of power lies in the Ring itself. Its creator, Sauron's desire for mastery consumed him, from a beautiful being of wisdom and skill to an embodiment of darkness driven solely by his lust for power. Once he forged the One Ring his descent was swift,. Likewise in Saruman,: his rise to betrayal, began once Boromir took hold of Rohan. He started seeking alliances through marriages and power-secrity but this ambition drove him further still into darkness - culminating finally in treason against Rohan and ultimately serving under Sauron.

Furthermore, even well-intentioned individuals risked becoming ensnarled when their authority increased excessively such as Denethor, steward ruler during Gondore during Pelenna. Through Isendeethur who advised them and thus,  they acted selfishly out of fears of falling; this also highlights pitfalls within structures or authorities.
